title: 108_hr1106
content:
The Act titled the "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" before discussing the conveyance of facilities. The Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho will receive conveyance of water distribution and drainage systems from the Secretary of the Interior as per the memorandum of agreement. The Secretary must transfer all rights to canals, laterals, and drains to the District. The Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho will receive water distribution and drainage systems from the Secretary of the Interior. If conveyance is not completed by September 13, 2004, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. SEC. 4. COSTS. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs and the net present value of remaining obligations for the conveyance of facilities under section 3. The Secretary will require the District to pay the net present value of remaining obligations for the conveyance of facilities under section 3, or $280,000, whichever is less. Amounts received will be deposited into the Reclamation Fund. The Secretary will convey the Teton Exchange Wells and related permit and equipment to the District. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in the Act are fulfilled. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Before conveyance, the Secretary must complete all environmental reviews as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a).

SEC. 7. LIABILITY

After conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages related to the conveyed facilities, except for negligence committed prior to the conveyance date. This does not increase the liability beyond what is currently provided in chapter 171 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 8. WATER SUPPLY TO DISTRICT LANDS.

The acreage eligible for water from the Minidoka and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include all current and annexed lands. This increase does not affect existing water storage contracts or State water law.

SEC. 9. DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to initiate a drought management planning process for all water uses. Within 18 months, a final drought management plan will be submitted to Congress. The Act does not affect existing rights, including those of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes to water based on treaties or laws. Conveyances under the Act do not impact contracts or state laws regarding water rights.
